title: john mcdonnell unveils labour policies
story: NewsJohn McDonnell unveils Labour policies for 15-year revolution with nationalisation, NHS and workers at its heartEXCLUSIVE : Shadow Chancellor outlines Labour's plan to depose Theresa May before Christmas, deliver real change for Britain and hold Tories to accountShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor22:01, 23 SEP 2018Updated22:03, 23 SEP 2018NewsAndrew Gregory interviews John McDonnell"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter eight years of Tory austerity that has plunged millions of Brits into a cycle of despair, Labour is now poised to ride to the rescue. And John McDonnell said Jeremy Corbyn hopes to topple Theresa May before Christmas to start reversing the damage of her war on the poor, disabled, public services, education and health. The Shadow Chancellor also said Labour is plotting a 15-year revolution in power that will put workers’ rights, the NHS, social care and industry at the heart of a bid to make Britain a fairer place to live once again. With the Tories in disarray over Brexit, the possibility of an autumn general election looms.  And in an exclusive interview with the Mirror, Mr McDonnell said: “We’re ready… and we’ll win. “I want the election as soon as possible. Eight years of Tory austerity has left people wanting real change. So we’ll provide them with a radical manesto. “We could be in place tomorrow. I think the third term will be our most exciting. “I think  the last election had lasted another week or two, we would be in government. “Everyone thought that was a flash in the pan, there was talk about ‘Peak Corbyn’. Actually, we’ve consolidated that. The polls now are between 38 and 44, permanently. We need another 4 or 5% to get into government. “Once we get into government, that first Queen’s Speech will be popular. We will put money into people’s pockets, provide a real living wage, restore trade union rights, end &shyprivatisation and start investing in public services and in the infrastructure that will give us the jobs.  “I want the Tories held to account for what they’ve done. Apart from eight years of austerity, their handling of Brexit has had a direct impact on the economy and people’s living standards. “I want them held to account. I want them out.” Mr McDonnell, 67, will today deliver a keynote speech at Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool – as the party maps out its vision of a Britain for all. It will unveil a radical plan that includes renationalising water, rail, energy and mail within the first five years of government. A National Care Service to tackle the social care crisis and end cuts will be launched. Labour is also planning a National Education Service to slash classroom sixes and increase teacher input.  Billions of pounds will be pumped into the NHS to restore it to the service that was the envy of the world until the Tories starting dismantling it. And workers could be &pound500 a year better off with the launch of “inclusive ownership” of big firms in a bid to narrow the wage gap between staff and bosses. Mr McDonnell will tell delegates: “Workers, who create the wealth of a company, should share in its ownership and, yes, in the s that it makes. If Labour does last three years, Mr McDonnell will by then be 82. But he insisted the next generation of MPs is ready for the &shychallenge of keeping the party in power. He added: “You’ve got the likes of Becky Long-Bailey, Richard Burgon, Angie Rayner, Kate Osamor. They’re committed, working class young people, with an eye for detail, really good advocates of our policy.” Mr McDonnell demanded the PM quit over her Brexit handling.   He said: “Theresa May has proved herself &shyincapable of negotiating her way out of a paper bag. I have no sympathy for her. “She’s got us into this mess, she’s got a responsibility to the country to go. Asked whether he believed the PM would secure an EU deal, he replied: “She’ll get some form of deal, probably a fudge. It won’t be one that even her own party will support.” Labour has set six tests for any deal including a strong relationship with Europe, the same rights, &shyprotections and benefits as now and fair migration.

title: labour could scrap universal credit
story: NewsLabour could SCRAP Universal Credit entirely reveals welfare chief as she launches sweeping review of the benefits systemEXCLUSIVE: Benefits chief Margaret Greenwood says "we're not ruling anything out" as she launches a year-long review of the chaos-hit welfare systemShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor21:00, 23 SEP 2018NewsTory welfare chief Esther McVey and, right, Jeremy Corbyn"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour dramatically opens the door tonight to scrapping the Tories' entire welfare reform Universal Credit. Benefits chief Margaret Greenwood refused to rule out the bombshell move after flaws and cuts in the system forced thousands of desperate families to foodbanks. The policy sht comes ahead of Ms Greenwood's address on Monday to the Labour Party Conference in Liverpool - where she will launch a year-long review into redesigning the “toxic” benefits system. Labour's official policy is to “pause and fix” UC. But disabled activists want to go further and “stop and scrap” it. Now Ms Greenwood has said she is “looking into” whether the multi-billion pound system should be scrapped entirely – adding: “We're not ruling anything out.”   Real Britain Fringe 2018: The Mirror takes powerful stories from Wigan Pier project to Labour Party Conference  In an exclusive interview with the Mirror, she also:  Said Labour would ban all benefit sanctions for people who turn up late to a JobCentre Confirmed Labour would end the benefits freeze by raising rates in line with inflation every year - something party chiefs stopped short of saying in last year's general election Claimed her ambition is to end all private firms carrying out disability benefit tests - but didn't fully commit to doing so Revealed Department for Work and Pensions  staff call their system the circle of hell.  Last week Tory ministers claimed ditching UC and reverting to the old system would cause massive disruption and be “complex and expensive - because the changes have become increasingly embedded. But the Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary said: We need to query that assertion. Because we need to know exactly what is and is not practicable to do. Asked  she could envisage Labour wanting to undo the whole of UC, she said: This is something we're sort of in the process of looking into.  Asked  she ruled out scrapping UC in its entirety she said: We're not ruling anything out, because we think it's important to be on top of all of the detail of it before making a decision. Ex-teacher Ms Greenwood became MP for Wirral West in 2015 – ousting now-Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey. During her speech she will announce a consultation into redesigning the entire benefits system, “changing the narrative” from punishment to support. It will invite contributions from Labour members, benefit claimants and charities and aim to form the blueprint for a new system by this time next year. She said Tory ministers have “vilied” people on benefits. “I meet a lot of people in their middle years who say 'I can't face going to the Jobcentre because I find it too humiliating',” she said.  “Well that's absolutely wrong, because those people have worked 20, 30 years, they're entitled to get support. “They shouldn't be made to feel that somehow there's a stigma attached to them.” She added: “If you talk to people working in the social security system at the moment, I've had it described to me as the circle of hell. “We're not going to be squandering money on a punitive regime which at the moment seems to have lost sight of itself. It seems to be punishment for punishment's sake.” Labour plans to take the &pound240million spent running benefit sanctions – which dock people's payments for a month – and spend it instead on “employment and careers support”.  Sanctions would not be wiped out completely, she admitted, but she claimed the system would move away from “punitive” measures. “We're not going to be saying we won't do anything  people are defrauding the system, of course we will,” Ms Greenwood said. “But when it comes to using a stick to beat people, when it comes to forcing people to jump through hoops, we're not prepared to do that.” Ms Greenwood told the Mirror she would ban any benefit sanctions for turning up late to a Jobcentre appointment. She added: “At the moment someone can be sanctioned for being late for a Jobcentre interview, missing the bus, and lose a month's money. “We think this is really punitive, unnecessary and highly damaging. “So what we're going to say is we will not continue with that regime. We will absolutely stop the punitive sanctions regime.”  But sanctions could continue for people who miss their entire appointments. Ms Greenwood said: “You'd have to look at what the reason was why they missed it.” The review will also look at the privately-run “assessments” for disability benefits PIP and ESA. The tests are regularly branded a failure after two-thirds of appeals against them were successful. Labour has vowed to scrap the current system but has not said what would come in its place. Asked  she would rule out outsourcing the tests to private firms in future, Ms Greenwood said: “I'd have to look at the costings of that. The ambition would be to, certainly.” Meanwhile there was confusion over Labour's policy last year when Jeremy Corbyn said the benefits freeze would end – but stopped short of saying rates would be raised in line with inflation. Speaking to the Mirror, however, Ms Greenwood said: “We would end the benefits freeze, and that would mean uprating in line with inflation every year.”

title: labours centre left politicians vow
story: NewsLabour's centre left politicians vow to stay and fight as they attacked praise of Militant, anti-Semitism and 'navel gazing'MPs, councillors and campaigners said they were not leaving the party or joining another despite often receiving abuse and being told to 'f*** off and join the Tories"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent20:51, 23 SEP 2018News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's centre left politicians vow to stay and fight as they attacked praise of Militant, anti-Semitism and 'navel gazing'.  At a rally of Progress - the group set up to help Tony Blair win power within Labour - MPs, councillors and campaigners said they were not leaving the party or joining another despite often receiving abuse and being told to 'f*** off and join the Tories.   In a defiant speech the Chair of Progress Alison McGovern admitted: Le in the Labour Party at the moment is far from easy and I know that sometimes the behaviour of those on the hard left who think they act on behalf of the leadership can cause us distress.   But the Wirral South MP said she would not leave Labour and would continue fighting for its goal of giving power to working people. She added: At times recently, we have seen the Labour movement at its worst. A party that cannot demonstrate it can deal with vile anti-Semitism can't govern and nor will it deserve to. Ilford North MP Wes Streeting attacked shadow equalities minister Dawn Butler's decision to praise Liverpool's Militant-dominated council for setting an illegal budget in the 1980s.  Mr Streeting said Militant's record was not something to celebrate on the platform of a Labour conference. He said: Back then, when the Labour Party was tearing itself apart with internal battles, families like mine were suffering under Tory government. Plans for a breakaway party were on the road to nowhere and Labour remained the only means for achieving progressive goals, he said.  But he warned that the introspection and battles over internal party procedures seen at the Liverpool conference were killing the promise and hope of our party and keeping this Tory Government in power. Mr Streeting urged Labour moderates to stand up for the proud centre-left tradition in our party and take on the toxic political culture that calls us Red Tories and shouts 'shame' at trade unionists on the conference floor .

title: len mccluskey says labour mps
story: NewsLen McCluskey says Labour MPs who criticise Jeremy Corbyn are 'almost asking to be deselected'The Unite general secretary warned the party leader's internal critics to fall in line or face the chopShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomOnline Political Editor17:04, 23 SEP 2018NewsLabour MPs who criticise Jeremy Corbyn are “almost asking to be deselected”, union chief Len McCluskey claimed "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour MPs who criticise Jeremy Corbyn are “almost asking to be deselected”, union chief Len McCluskey claimed today. The Unite general secretary warned the party leader's internal critics to fall in line or face the chop. Corbyn supporters want beefed-up powers making it easer to oust MPs seen as disloyal to the Labour boss. They believe boosting democracy in constituency parties will give members a better chance of getting rid of candidates who fail to give him sufficient backing. Supporting mandatory reselection, Mr McCluskey told the Mirror/Unite Real Britain fringe: “I believe there are certain MPs within our party who are almost asking to be deselected.”  As activists cheered and applauded, he went on: “They really don't want to be part of this exciting transformation that's taking place. “All my le I have sought a government that would bring about the irreversible sht in balance of power in favour of working people. “We now have an opportunity.” Members who railed against MPs were not guilty of “bullying” but wanted to exercise “accountability”, he insisted. “You've already heard the terminology of 'bullying' and 'intimidation ' and 'intolerance,” said the workers' leader. “I've got another word for them – it's called 'accountability'.  “It's not about bullying, it's about simply wanting people to be accountable to the very people who go out night in night out in the wind and the rain to try and persuade people to vote them into power. “We want accountability and we will get it.” Earlier, Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth hit out at activists from Momentum, the grassroots campaign group loyal to Mr Corbyn, who have called for every sitting MP to face a full, open selection. They should unite and focus on the real enemy, he said. It comes after a row erupted on the conference floor over the issue between Corbyn supporters and trade unions, who were in favour of a compromise. Mr Ashworth said: I think it's disappointing when we heard on the conference floor people shouting 'shame on the trade unions'.  I'm a trade unionist, that's why I'm in the Labour Party .   I think we've got a compromise on the table, it's a compromise that has been supported by Jeremy Corbyn , and supported by John McDonnell.

title: real britain fringe 2017 mirror
story: NewsReal Britain Fringe 2018: The Mirror takes powerful stories from Wigan Pier project to Labour Party ConferenceGeorge Orwell would be shocked at modern Real Britain, our annual event to showcase the victims of austerity heard todayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:56, 23 SEP 2018Updated17:06, 23 SEP 2018News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShadow chancellor John McDonnell said George Orwell would be shocked by how bad Britain is today. He was speaking alongside victims of cruel Tory austerity yesterday told of their misery as the Mirror’s Real Britain fringe gave them a voice. They revealed their suffering in moving speeches which left some delegates at the Labour Conference fringe in tears. Ros Wynne Jones has been retracing the route George Orwell took to write The Road to Wigan Pier and telling the stories of those who Tory Britain has left behind. She told the fringe meeting: “One of the huge frustrations for us 80 years on is seeing the loss of potential in working class communities up and down the country.” The Mirror journalist explained how she had spent five years documenting the human consequences of Tory austerity and how the Wigan Pier Project.  She said: “I did a trip to Wigan in 2015 and I met a vicar in her church where there were lots of people sleeping and a foodbank and she said Orwell would weep  he could see Wigan now. Ros has spoken to 200 people along this route. She explained: “Orwell wanted comfortably off Britain to listen to the other Britain and it is something that holds true today.”  She said that it came as no surprise to her travelling around the country and hearing people’s stories that in many of these areas people voted to leave the EU -often because they wanted to be heard. “Our response to that can’t be to tell people they’re stupid and racist,” she said. Ros told the packed meeting: “Ten years on it shouldn’t be the bankers at Lehman brothers that are having a party, it’s us who should be celebrating the fact that these communities have survived at all.” Ros was joined by Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, General Secretary of Unite the Union Len McCluskey and footballer turned campaigner Neville Southall.  But she also introduced two 'real' people to the conference whose experiences showed how the government's policies are destroying families and communities. Stacey Bridge ran into financial problems after not being able to afford her dad’s funeral after he was violently murdered in Liverpool. She ended up homeless and at the Merseyside Youth Foodbank - a special foodbank for young people in Liverpool. But after relying on the food bank she is now a volunteer and also coaches football. “It’s more than a bag of food,” she said, explaining how a young woman had got onto a music course with her help and support.  Amina Weston told of the devastation of being made homeless by an unscrupulous landlord when she was pregnant in a moving poem she had written about her experiences. She is currently bringing up her baby in temporary accommodation in Leeds but she’s still managed to set up Education Aid with her sister - a charity to help families with school unorms.  She described losing her home: “My world torn apart my le ripped from under me.” Adding: “Anxiety, paranoia and depression are my new friends”. Although Amina has struggled she has managed to set up an education charity with her sister to help families with school unorms called Education Aid. But she warned: “This could happen to anyone”.  Shadow chancellor John McDonnell praised Ros and the Mirror for the work of the Real Britain column. He said: “It’s been fundamental in exposing some of the experiences people are having in this country and the shame we should be feeling.”  Len McCluskey also praised Ros's work and the Mirror's campaigning. Week-in-week-out it exposes whats actually going on in the real world. He said that Amina's poem and it brought tears to my eyes and it makes you realise we're about - we're about fighting for fairness, for decency for justice, for all people. The panel also boasted Neville Southall legendary Everton and Wales goalkeeper turned social media activist. When not using his 144,000-follower Twitter account to berate the Tories, Nev hands it over to people who he believes need a wider audience – child abuse charities, drugs helplines, LGBT+ causes and even sex workers. The passionate campaigner spoke of his frustration with the lack of progress on those areas he cares strongly about.

title: vladimir putin waging second cold
story: NewsVladimir Putin is waging a second cold war - and he's winning, warns Tom WatsonThe Deputy Labour Leader warned the Kremlin had "reinvented blitzkrieg for the digital age"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter19:00, 23 SEP 2018Updated19:16, 23 SEP 2018NewsPutin has 'reinvented blitzkrieg for the digital age' "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailVladimir Putin is waging a second cold war - and this time he’s winning, Tom Watson warned today. The Deputy Labour Leader said the Kremlin had reinvented blitzkrieg for the digital age through a campaign of misinformation, malicious technology and dark money.  He suggested Theresa May 'declined' a request from security services to investigate Russian influence ahead of the the Brexit referendum.  And a whistleblower claimed Russian agents may still be actively infiltrating and undermining political networks in the UK.  Speaking at an event on the Fringe of Labour Party Conference, Mr Watson called for a full-scale pubic inquiry into Russian influence in the Brexit Referendum.   Mr Watson said it was a “dark story about the frontiers of the new Cold War. “It’s dark because it is turbo powered by tech. “And unlike the last cold war, Putin’s Russia is winning.” Mr Watson said: “All of us need to wake up to the true scale of what’s been going on. “Now is the time when the government must drop the three wise monkeys act: see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil - about the biggest threat to the integrity of our democracy. The Russian attack. “It’s time we woke up to the reality that Russia has reinvented the blitzkreig for the digital age. A new strategy to attack far behind our old defences, to attack us from within. “They’re prepared to kill on the streets of Salisbury. But just as dangerous is their long war to ide and rule.” He added: “This is where we need government agencies and authorities to step in, but I’m not confident that they will.” Mr Watson has joined forces with fellow Labour MPs Darren Jones and Liam Byrne to launch a petition calling for a full public inquiry, with powers similar to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's inquiry into alleged Russian interference in the US election. He said: “Without the powers to interview under caution, to subpoena documents and transactions records and to request assistance from foreign jurisdictions, such networks are practically impossible to crack.”  If such a petition were to gain 100,000 signatures, it could force the issue to be debated on the floor of the House of Commons. Mr Watson also claimed to have been told Theresa May, while she was Home Secretary, declined a request from the security services to investigate Leave.EU founder Arron Banks. He said: I don't know  this is true, and none of us will  there isn't a proper investigation Whatever the Prime Minister did or didn’t do now is the time for the truth to out. The Mirror has approached the Home Office for comment. A spokesman for Arron Banks said the request was declined because there was nothing to investigate.

title: anxiety levels higher ever thanks
story: NewsAnxiety levels higher than ever thanks to pressures of modern le, research claimsA study has found that work, home le and social pressures have contributed to a rise in anxiety which now affects 40 per cent of BritsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGemma Francis19:23, 23 SEP 2018NewsAnxiety is on the rise in 2018 due to ious lestyle pressures "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe demands of modern le are making more of us anxious than ever before, it has been claimed. Researchers who carried out a detailed study found pressure at work, home and in our social lives has lead 40 per cent of the nation to now believe they suffer from some sort of anxiety. More than one in five reckon they are now more fretful, edgy or tense than they were five years ago with health concerns their major worry. Others have become more stressed about taking time off work, socialising, their finances and their career.  The study, by wellness brand Healthspan’s CBD oil  supplement, also found six in 10 of those suffering from anxiety have even sought medical advice from their GP. Another six in 10 have turned to exercise to try and combat the issue, while 59 per cent reliant on medication and supplements, such as CBD oil. Dr Jen Bateman a clinical psychologist on behalf of Healthspan says: ‘The rise in both social anxiety and anxiety is due to a range of factors. “Our lives are becoming busier and can feel overwhelming - we’re constantly striving for more and better. “Worldwide events are being streamed into the phone in the palm of our hands in our highly-connected digital worlds, and it’s challenging to ‘switch-off’, which our brains need to rest and stay calm. “The constant stream of demands and data is overpowering for many, especially for those with a vulnerability to developing anxiety.” The study also found 62 per cent of people believe le is becoming increasingly more anxiety-provoking with the average adult rating their anxiety levels at almost three out of five – with five being very severe. One in twenty put their anxiety at a full five.  It also emerged anxiety sufferers will struggle four times a day with their condition, but more than three quarters will keep it quiet from others around them. Anxiety has a huge effect on the lives of some sufferers though with almost one in 10 saying the condition led to them losing their job while another 19 per cent quit their role. Sufferers have also seen others end relationships , lose friends , put on weight  or avoid socialising . Worryingly, the study, carried out via OnePoll, found many are suffering in silence with just 28 per cent admitting they feel comfortable talking to their friends or work colleagues about their anxiety. Dr Sarah Brewer added: “A tsunami of anxiety is impacting all areas of people’s lives and health. “Many are turning to products like cannabidiol to treat anxiety so it’s not surprising that CBD Oil is one of the fastest growing health trends. “But the recent Government U-turn to legalise medical marijuana has left consumers confused and just one in 10 said they would know what to look for when buying a CBD supplement.  “As the market is becoming flooded with new products that look ethical but contain few active ingredients, it’s important to select a quality product. “I recommend looking for a supplier who provides an independent analysis certication showing the actual level of CBD  and THC  - products that simply claim to use ‘whole plant extract’ are misleading. “You should also compare the actual milligram  levels of cannabidiol  in the product and ensure the company is a member of the Cannabis Trade Association. “Also, check with your GP or a pharmacist  you are taking prescribed medication, as CBD oil can interact with certain drugs, including those used to treat anxiety and depression.”

title: calls ban new drivers carrying
story: NewsCoroner calls for a ban on new drivers carrying passengers after two teenagers died in horror crashCoroner is writing to the Government to request they introduce “graduated” driving licences and the families of the two girls who died are backing himShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJeremy Armstrong19:24, 23 SEP 2018Updated19:29, 23 SEP 2018NewsThe deaths of Skye Mitchell, pictured, and her friend have sparked calls for a ban on newly qualied drivers taking passengers "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA coroner has called for a ban on newly qualied drivers carrying passengers after a smash that killed two teenagers.  Lelong pals Skye Mitchell and Caitlin Huddleston, both 18, died when Skye’s Toyota Yaris crashed into a van when she lost control on a bend .  She had passed her test four months before the tragedy. Cumbria assistant coroner Robert Chapman is writing to the Government to request “graduated” driving licences.  MPs and safety groups are also backing such a scheme, as operated in the US, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand. Sky and Caitlin, of Millom, Cumbria, were killed last July on the A595. Mr Chapman ruled they died of multiple injuries and added the Yaris was travelling a little too fast for the wet conditions.  He said: “It wouldn’t have been too fast  the road had been dry. But she was inexperienced. “I am going to make a report to the Department for Transport. “What I am concerned about is that once people have passed their test, they have a graduated driving licence.”

title: couple try lure two schoolgirls
story: NewsCouple 'try to lure two schoolgirls into their car by asking  they would like to stroke their puppy'The 11-year-olds were told that they could keep the dog  they got in the car, it is claimedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJim Hardy18:24, 23 SEP 2018Updated18:33, 23 SEP 2018NewsThe incident happened as the girls walked home from school "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple reportedly tried to coax two little girls into their car by asking  they wanted to pet a puppy. The 11-year-old school girls had been walking home through a car park when a man and a woman are said to have bribed the girls with a dachshund. According to the terried girls the pair had told them that they could take the puppy home  they got in the car. The incident happened at around 3.40pm on Wednesday, in the Queens Hill area of Costessy in Norfolk. The girls ran off, and the man and woman drove away in the Longwater direction.  The mother of one of the girls told police that the man had asked them: 'Do you want to stroke the puppy...get in the car and you can have it’. He was in the passenger seat, sitting sideways with the door open. The girls were 'really shaken up and frightened' by the possible attempted abduction according to their families. Luckily their school did a 'safety class' about not talking to strangers a few days ago so it was fresh in their minds. Local families are now warning their children amid fears the pair could strike again. One mum-of-two who asked not to be named said: If it had been younger children, they might well have been tempted to get into the car to see the puppy.

title: lord lucan mystery could finally
story: NewsLord Lucan mystery could finally be solved from beyond the grave after brother dies leaving unpublished bookPapers from Hugh Bingham, who passed away in South Africa, may reveal the truth about what happened to his brother after he fled the murder sceneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndy Lines18:11, 23 SEP 2018Updated18:13, 23 SEP 2018NewsThe death of Lord Lucan's brother may prove to be the first step to unravelling the truth of what happened to him "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLord Lucan’s brother has died, sparking speculation that the mystery of the notorious baron’s disappearance could finally be solved from beyond the grave. Hugh Bingham passed away at the age of 78 in South Africa in July, but his death was only revealed this weekend. Experts believe there may be documents and letters among his personal effects that could reveal what happened to his brother. Mr Bingham was also working on a book, which may contain further information about the mystery.  Lord Lucan vanished in 1974. He fled his home in Belgravia, Central London, after killing the family nanny, Sandra Rivett, 29. James Sanders, an investigative journalist who knew him well, said Mr Bingham would often hint that he had information about Lord Lucan’s fate, but failed to provide any solid evidence.  Mr Sanders told the Mail on Sunday : “He would talk at  about his brother’s innocence, yet refused to reveal  Lucan was still alive or where he had lived.  “It was impossible to know  they were in touch, though it seemed likely.”  Mr Bingham had been living a reclusive le in a suburb of Johannesburg, where he had worked as librarian for the Theosophical Society, a non-religious organisation. The Oxford graduate moved to South Africa months after his brother’s disappearance. This sparked unsubstantiated rumours that he may have been in contact with his sibling, who had managed to slip out of Britain. Mr Bingham – who always maintained that his brother was innocent – had been ghostwriting Lord Lucan’s “autobiography”. The book was due to put forward theories about his possible escape from England, and detail ious guises that he may then have adopted.  Speaking in 2016, after the High Court declared his brother dead, Mr Bingham said: “John had no option but to flee. He would have considered his chances of a fair trial to be very slim.” Mr Bingham said one of the theories covered in his book was that Lord Lucan escaped Britain with a fake passport and built a new le as a farm manager in KwaZulu Natal province, South Africa. Lord and Lady Veronica Lucan were fighting for custody of their three children. He is thought to have killed Ms Rivett after mistaking her for his we.

story: NewsParents of boy with Down's syndrome are raffling off their £1.75m London flat as he can't get down stairsCliodhna and husband Stuart are asking those interested in their Maida Vale flat to buy a £25 raffle ticket for the chance to win it and there are runner-up cash prizes tooShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRichard Jenkins19:25, 23 SEP 2018Updated19:35, 23 SEP 2018NewsA couple are selling their flat via raffle to make a change for their seven-year-old son with severe Down's syndrome "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe parents of a boy with Down’s syndrome are raffling off their luxury &pound1.75m London flat because he can no longer get down the stairs. Cliodhna Ross, 46, and husband Stuart are hoping to sell their four-bedroom Maida Vale property by asking potential new owners to pay &pound25-a-ticket to win it, mortgage free. The family have no need to leave their dream home, but for the fact they are beginning to struggle carrying seven-year-old Ollie up and down the stairs. Financial services project manager Cliodhna, 46, said: “We knew almost as soon as he was born that Ollie had Down’s syndrome.  His condition comes with delayed learning and general mobility, but in general that doesn’t seem to be much of a problem. However having had all the loft work done and turned the flat into our ideal home, we realised Ollie wasn’t terribly mobile and was struggling to get steady on his legs. We simply cannot get him to go downstairs.  And  he wants to go upstairs you have to heft him over your shoulders which has become much harder as he’s grown older.” The Rosses have lived in the upmarket west London apartment building since 2001.  In that time they secured planning permission to extend into the roof area, creating a rooftop terrace with astonishing views of London’s skyline. But after realising the dficulties Ollie will increasingly have navigating his way up down the floors in the mansion block, the Rosses put their home on the market to find something more suited to his needs, and those of his sister Issy, eight. However, due to market fluctuations, the house remained unsold. Cliodhna said: “We went from having all the room we needed to having to move.  “We put our property on the market in April this year but the timing was appalling – nobody wanted to buy an expensive property in Central London. ‘’People are simply not putting their properties on the market unless they absolutely have to. “If you do sell your property at a bargain price, chances are you won’t be able to afford a replacement property. ‘’Eventually we took 10 per cent off the price and still couldn’t find a buyer.  “The kids are now happily settled in school, and Ollie is settled at his special needs school so we don’t want to disrupt them by moving too far away.” The luxurious apartment sprawls over the third and fourth floors of a well-maintained, red-brick mansion block on one of Maida Vale’s wide avenues. It features four bedrooms, two balconies, a sitting room and a large kitchen/diner, as well as two bathrooms and a cloakroom.  It’s also unique in having its own private roof terrace, as well as access to the building’s communal garden which is maintained by a professional gardener. The property covers approximately 1,500 square feet and comes complete with high-spec kitchen appliances from Bosch, Neff and Siemens. Outside the front door, just minutes away are the boutique stores of Lauderdale Parade and Clton Road, and it’s just a short walk from the scenic canals of Little Venice.  Since setting up the raffle in May, thousands of tickets have been sold – but the couple are a long way from having the minimum number needed to cover the cost of the four-bedroom flat. Cliodhna and house-husband Stuart, 50, are hoping to have sold at least 85,000 tickets before the closing deadline of December 31st, to find the perfect forever-home for their family.  A percentage of the ticket sales will cover fees, and also be shared equally between two charities. The first is KIDS, which provides support services to disabled children, young people and their families. The second is The London Community Foundation, which designs and manages funds on behalf of those philanthropic iniduals and organisations that wish to tackle poverty, inequality and exclusion across the capital.  In addition, there is a &pound100,000 second prize and five runner-up prizes of &pound10,000 in cash each. Entrants will not only have to pay &pound25 for a ticket, but complete a crossword, to stay on the right side of strict gambling regulations. And the winner will also be liable to pay stamp duty on the property, as well as any usual apartment block maintenance costs.

story: NewsPrincess Diana pathologist who examined her body answers rumours she was pregnant when she diedDr Richard Shepherd, now 65, re-examined Diana's body for the official inquiry into her death - since then, people have asked him: "Was she pregnant?"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans10:14, 23 SEP 2018Updated20:21, 23 SEP 2018NewsDr Richard Shepherd re-examined Princess Diana's body for the official inquiry into her death "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A leading forensic pathologist who examined Princess Diana's body has addressed rumours the princess was pregnant when she died in a Paris car crash.  Dr Richard Shepherd, who has worked on more than 23,000 dead bodies, re-examined Diana's for the official inquiry into her death two decades ago. Unsurprisingly, people asked him ious questions about the princess's body after the second autopsy, such as whether she was beautul and peaceful. Others questioned: Was she pregnant? Since Diana's death, there have been repeated claims she was expecting a child when she and her lover, Dodi Fayed, died in the horror crash in the French capital.  Dodi's father, Mohamed Al Fayed, claimed the 36-year-old princess had told him she was pregnant in a phone call shortly before the tragedy in August 1997. And in 2007, a French investigative journalist alleged Diana was almost certainly nine to 10 weeks pregnant when her and her lover's Mercedes crashed. But addressing the pregnancy question, Dr Shepherd said there was no pathological evidence that the princess was expecting a baby when she died.  Speaking to the Daily Mail , the dad-of-two, now 65, said: Pathologically there was no evidence that Princess Diana was pregnant, but some women say they know they're pregnant from the moment of conception. Was she one of those?   He left the question 'hanging', according to the newspaper.  The pathologist, whose new memoir has just been published, also claimed that Diana would have been here for son Prince Harry's wedding to Meghan Markle at Windsor Castle, Berkshire, in May  she had worn her seatbelt.  If she had taken this step, he believes she would have survived the tragedy in the Pont de l'Alma road tunnel with a black eye or maybe a broken arm. Driver Henri Paul, said to have been twice the British drink-drive limit, also died in the devastating car crash. The only survivor was bodyguard Trevor Rees.  A string of official enquiries later ruled Diana and Dodi, 42, died in an accident when their French driver crashed their car while drunk in the tunnel. The jury at the princess's inquest found the pair had been unlawfully killed and their deaths were the result of “gross negligence” on the part of Henri and paparazzi who were following the vehicle on motorbikes. During his career, Dr Shepherd, who has two children, Chris, 37, and Anna, 35, and three stepdaughters, has worked on other major incidents.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: 'Indian summer' to begin TOMORROW but Britain will face North-South ideThe Met Office have forecast that one swathe of the country will enjoy sunshine and still weather but the other half will be left battling wind and rainShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter08:48, 23 SEP 2018Updated09:02, 23 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/rain-incoming-watch-weather-forecast-13288147,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An Indian Summer is forecast to begin tomorrow however the country will suffer a North/South ide in the days to come. Woman heartbroken by husband's death reveals amazing way he continues to save lives  She was rushed to Royal Preston Hospital where medics discovered she had a tumour. story: NewsBrave seduction trick girl, 14, used on Nazis before executing them herself in woodlandFreddie Oversteegen, who died aged 92 this month, blew up bridges and railway lines, smuggled Jewish children out of concentration camps and shot Nazis during WW2Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans16:30, 23 SEP 2018Updated17:30, 23 SEP 2018NewsFreddie Oversteegen was just 14 when she joined the Dutch resistance against the Nazis "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPetite with plaited hair, Freddie Oversteegen was just 14 when she and her big sister left their family home and joined the Dutch resistance against the Nazis. With one rule from their mother, Always stay human, the pair, along with red-haired pal Hannie Schaft, carried out a campaign of sabotage against Nazi invaders. The siblings learned how to shoot, sabotaged bridges and railway lines with dynamite, and smuggled Jewish children out of concentration camps during World War Two . In an incredibly brave act, they also tricked Nazi men using seduction - so they could lure them to a secluded spot in the Netherlands and execute them. Although the pair and Hannie all had youthful looks, Freddie was the youngest and reportedly appeared at least two years younger than her actual age.  Her innocent looks meant she was easily overlooked as a potential threat by Nazi officials, who would rarely stop her as she passed by on her bicycle. Unbeknown to the officials, she had firearms hidden in her bike basket. As part of their trick, Freddie and the other two girls would seduce their targets in bars and ask them  they wanted to go for a stroll, the Washington Post reports. After the Nazi collaborators agreed to do so, the youngsters would lead them into a wooded area where, instead of a kiss, they would receive a bullet. In a later interview, Freddie, the first of the girls to kill a soldier, said: We had to do it. She added: It was a necessary evil, killing those who betrayed the good people. Freddie, who was only seven when Adolf Hitler came to power, died earlier this month, just a day before her 93rd birthday, according to the  .  The 92-year-old passed away on September 5 in a nursing home close to where she, her older sister Truus and Hannie had courageously sabotaged the Nazis. She and Truus had joined the resistance after a man turned up at their front door. Speaking to VICE decades after the war, Freddie recalled: A man wearing a hat came to the door and asked my mother  he could ask us [to fight in the resistance]. And he did, so yes, she was okay with it. The siblings' and Hannie's targets reportedly included high-ranking Nazi officers. And as well as luring their targets into woodland and executing them, the group would help to smuggle Jewish kids across the country and out of 'death camps'. They would also gun down Nazis from a bike during the occupation of the Netherlands. A loved one recalled how, after the Oversteegen siblings were taught to shoot, Truus would ride on a bicycle with Freddie sitting on the back shooting.  The relative said that because they were girls, they went unnoticed. In addition to developing shooting skills, the sisters learned to march in the woods. Later, a Nazi big shot was executed at the same site by a male member of the resistance after being seduced in a bar and lured there by Truus. That day, Freddie's job was to keep a lookout from a vantage point. Truus had met him in an expensive bar, seduced him and then took him for a walk in the woods. She was like: 'Want to go for a stroll?', she later told VICE. And of course he wanted to. But during the 'stroll', the Nazi was gunned down. Freddie recalled how his hole had already been dug, but we weren't allowed to be there for that part. Before the war, the Oversteegen family, who lived on a barge, had hidden people from Lithuania in the hold of their ship.

On examining her, I noticed that the safety pin was open and lodged inside her nostril. I got her x-ray done, and told the parents that it is a problematic case. I informed them that the pin could be removed only after giving general anesthesia to the patient, and there were chances of injury as the pin wedged inside was causing constant bleeding.   Beautician's Beyonc&eacute surgery nightmare as 'botched' Brazilian butt lt in Turkey leaves her mis-shapen  The general anaesthetic could only be administered after six hours of fasting so the procedure could not begin until 10.30pm. And because of limited equipment, Dr Bhattacharya had to use an endoscope and his fingers to manually to locate the safety pin.

title: highly hazardous volcano katla ready
story: News'Highly hazardous' volcano Katla ready to erupt and could dwarf 2010 ash cloud that caused flight chaosKatla's explosion could produce an ash cloud three times the size of the one which brought air traffic to a standstill in 2010.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAsa Svensson14:24, 23 SEP 2018NewsA warning sign at the base of Katla "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 'highly hazardous' volcano is ready to blow and when it does it could produce an ash cloud three times the size of the one which grounded flights in 2010. Historically Katla – Icelandic for kettle or boiler – in Iceland has erupted every 50 years but its been a century since it last went off. That means an explosion is long overdue and its showing all the signs it could happen sooner rather than later. Its cone is hidden under a glacier on a 5,000ft peak so monitoring it is dficult but Icelandic and British scientists have noticed it's producing 'huge' levels of carbon dioxide.  That suggests its magma chambers could be filling, one of the precursors to an eruption, reports The Sunday Times. If it does blow its mammoth size means a giant ash cloud three times as large as the one which wreaked travel chaos in 2010 could be produced.  Thousands of passengers were left stranded when Eyjafjallajokull's plume grounded flights across Europe. A report by Evgenia Ilyinskaya, of Leeds University's Institute of Geophysics and Tectonics, found Katla is producing between 12 and 24 kilotons of carbon dioxide a day. Only two volcanoes are known to emit more.  Describing Katla as highly hazardous she said CO2 being released at such a scale usually suggests an eruption is on the cards. She said: : This is a clear sign we need to keep an eye of Katla. She isn't just doing nothing, and these findings confirm that there is something going on.

title: mh370 pilot was obsessed online
story: NewsMH370 pilot sent dozens of sexual and flirty messages to model twins in months before disappearanceExperts say the behaviour of Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah, the pilot in command when MH370 suddenly disappeared, should have raised alarm bellsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLuke Kenton07:17, 23 SEP 2018Updated17:19, 23 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/tv/video/experts-sit-down-discuss-what-12532083,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new investigation into the disappearance of the doomed MH370 flight has unearthed worrying details about the pilot's personal le. Captain Zaharie Ahmad Shah was in command when the Malaysian Airlines flight carrying 238 other passengers and crew vanished mid-flight in 2014. Hundreds of theories have been put forward for the Boeing 777's sudden disappearance, but new evidence could point the finger of blame towards Shah, after the discovery of his social media activity suggested a man with 'self-destructive' tendencies.  In the year leading up the MH370 mystery, Shah used Facebook to pursue Malaysian twin-sister models 34 years younger than him, leaving sexually suggestive comments on numerous occasions.   The 26-year-old sisters, Lan Qi Hui and Qi Min Lan, received more than 97 messages from Shah during 2013 - most of which were ignored. Shah persistently urged the twins to visit Kuala Lumpar - where he lived with his we - and responded to one photo of Qi Min Lan in a bathrobe, asking 'Just shower?' On top of his obsessive messages to the girls, Zaharie frequently publicly criticised the Malaysian government, despite working for a state-owned airline.   MH370's final message revealed as frantic air traffic controllers desperately tried to make contact with the plane  In April 2013, leading up to the election of then-prime minister Najib Razak, Shah posted 119 times about Razak, before responding to his appointment with: 'There is a rebel in each and every one of us. Let it out!' He later went on to describe Razak as a 'moron'. Aviation expert and editor-in-chief of airlineratings, Geoffrey Thomas, said it was alarming for a senior pilot to make political comments at all.  Thomas said: It should have raised serious alarm bells with the airline that you have someone flying who has such strong anti-government views. If a Qantas pilot did something like that, he would be spoken to and grounded. UK-based psychologist, Paul Dickens said: I think what you’re seeing is a degree of obsessional behaviour mixed with recklessness, which is unusual for a pilot.

title: as it happens falkirk v dundee united
story: Second-half headers from Pavol Safranko and Craig Curran see the points headed back to Dundee.Dundee United laboured for much of the first-half but opened the scoring in the second 45 through Safranko&#8217s header from a Fraser Aird delivery on 59 minutes.Curran made it two on 86 minutes as he flicked a lovely looped header over the Bairns&#8217 goalkeeper Leo Fasan from Yannick Loemba&#8217s cross.The win sees the Terrors move up to third in the Championship &#8211 just two points behind leaders Ayr United.Full match details in the live blog below.

title: braeview academy pupils cheered up by visit from dundee united footballers
story: Pupils from Braeview Academy were visited by Dundee United football players. 100vw, 3000px" /The S1 pupils have been spending time at the Fairfield Community Sports Hub after their school was partially damaged in a fire.John Cairney, projects officer from the sports centre, said: “We have been trying to keep the days as fun-filled as possible. They have been doing some football quizzes.The youngsters got the chance to put some questions to the players during the visit.Jamie Kirk from Dundee United Community Trust said: “The venue is fantastic and it’s great the community has such a great asset on their doorstep.“The community has really rallied around the school at a tough time and I’m really pleased to be able to have played a part in supporting the pupils and teachers.“Education is a really important part of what we do.“I have got to give huge credit to my team for stepping forward to help.”

title: calum woodger csaba laszlo is handling dundee uniteds current situation as well as can be expected
story: In what are trying – but not necessarily desperate – times for Dundee United, manager Csaba Laszlo appears to be handling their current situation as well as can be expected.Whether or not the blame for the position United currently find themselves in, namely being stuck in the Championship for a third season on the bounce, lies at Csaba’s door is up for debate.However, what cannot be denied is – since last season’s promotion play-off failure – the Hungarian has, largely, stuck to his word.He promised to remain committed to the club and be around for the squad overhaul he carried out over the summer.That facelt, along with a change in the Tangerines’ style of play, came and has been shown to work on the whole.Yet, as with most clubs up and down the country, other factors have got in the way of the master-plan and caused the Terrors to get off to a somewhat sticky start to the season.Injuries to key men from last season – Fraser Fyvie, Sam Stanton, Billy King and Stewart Murdoch – haven’t helped.New signing Nicky Clark, the man charged with putting the finishing touches on what is undeniably now Csaba’s team, has also had an Achilles problem.Csaba has combated these issues by tinkering with personnel, altering formations and, at times, being forced to field players out of position.Following Saturday’s 1-1 home draw with Morton, he said: “I know how painful it is to lose two points because you want to be at the top of the league but we are still just three points behind first and there are a lot of games to go.“I think we have a good team and we can dominate every game, we just need to be more clinical.“I want to keep clean sheets but, unfortunately, in every game we have conceded goals. We have been forced to change the defence with Murdoch out with a knee injury.“In the first 20 minutes, with Rachid Bouhenna starting, maybe not everyone was comfortable.“Afterwards we grew into the game and I don’t think that we made any mistakes.”Excuses, perhaps, but valid ones? Probably. Further to his points, when King, Paul McMullan and Fyvie, in particular, came on United kicked into gear.Ahead of Saturday’s trip to Falkirk, for the first time in a few weeks, Csaba will have options to consider from a squad he has, for all his critics, united behind one cause.Stanton is expected back in training while the trio aforementioned will have played themselves into the gaffer’s thoughts.Arabs heading through on Saturday will be looking for three points after draws against Alloa and Morton in their last two league matches.And rightly so, to push themselves back into promotion contention they will have to pick up three points with more regularity.However, Csaba has defended their record so far which sees them lie in fth position – just three points behind leaders Inverness Caley Thistle, saying: “We have had four games in a row without losing – two wins and two draws – so psychologically the team are showing spirit which is good.“They  have stuck with us for three years, this is the third year in the Scottish Championship and I think, not just the fans, but everybody is hoping we can go up.“This is a normal reaction, I understand them but they also must understand that we are also human and are trying to do the best for the club.“The fans have to appreciate the work that has been put in, the season is just beginning and it is only five games.”

title: dundee boss neil mccann has three games to save his job
story: Patience is wearing thin with the Dundee hierarchy and manager Neil McCann has just three matches to save his job.The Tele understands the Dark Blues boss has until the next international break to turn his side’s fortunes around.However, a heavy loss to Hibs today followed by defeat to Hamilton next week could accelerate that process.The Tele also believes there is appetite for change at Dens and owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms have been urged to sound out potential successors to McCann.However, the key decision-makers at the club are prepared to give the current gaffer more time to get the results that could kickstart the Dark Blues’ season.That patience will only last so long, though.Next week’s trip to Hamilton is followed by a home game against Steve Clarke’s Kilmarnock before the Premiership takes another break with international football taking over.By then, results are a must  Neil is continue in his role as manager.Meanwhile, the Dens gaffer will be hoping for a midfield boost today against Hibs.Glen Kamara has missed almost the entire season, starting just the opening Betfred Cup group stage win over Stirling Albion and the 1-0 defeat at St Johnstone three weeks ago.The Finnish international injured his ankle after that victory in Stirling and has struggled on with it since.He suffered a recurrence a fortnight ago as he prepared to travel to join up with his national side and then missed last week’s trip to Ibrox.He has, though, ed to training this week and is hoping to be fit enough to play a part against the Hibees at Dens today.

title: dundee council urged to speed up land sales after just 62 affordable homes built in a year
story: Council bosses have been urged to speed up the sale of land for new homes to be built on across Dundee – after falling behind on their housebuilding targets.Just 62 affordable homes – offering low rent to people on modest incomes – were built in 2017-18, short of the 200 the council had planned. The authority has a strategy to build 1,000 by 2021.Numerous families across the city are desperate to move to more suitable properties but feel stuck in their current homes due to a lack of supply.Barry Lamont, a full-time parent to D-Jay, 9, and Rudi, 5, is keen to get out of his Hilltown home, which he shares with partner, Gemma, 25, who is also a full-time parent to their children.Barry said: “At the moment we are confined to the multi. Rudi has mobility problems which are likely to get worse.&#8220He uses a wheelchair intermittently, but being in a multi, even the first floor is not ideal. It seems people are declaring themselves homeless so they jump the queue. My landing, for antisocial behaviour, is getting worse and worse.“The council and housing associations need to realise families need homes – especially children with disabilities.“You can’t overlook them, they are some of our most vulnerable people.”Bruce Forbes, of Angus Housing Association, says there are issues around freeing up land for such developments.He said: “At the moment we are going to build 32 houses in Mid Craigie and most of our developments have been in Whitfield. The problem we’ve got is the council is unable to progress with the sale of sites in Whitfield for us to develop.“We could be building 120 more houses there but we can’t because they can’t sell the land.“The council own all of the land there and  they were able to progress with that quicker then we would be able to get houses built there. We are building four-in-a-block-type houses and semi-detached-style properties which are hugely popular and we get bombarded with applications for them.”The council insists it is making progress, with 527 units under construction.Kevin Cordell, convener of neighbourhood services – which includes housing – said: “We recognise the need for new affordable housing, that’s why we have committed to building 1,000 affordable new homes.“In Mill o’ Mains, Whitfield, Lochee and Hilltown, we have already built more than 200.“We are getting to grips with the problem of supply and demand by rebalancing the amount and type of housing on offer to the people of Dundee.”

title: dundees paul mcgowan weve not been good enough and need to change that against hibernian
story: For Dundee’s players, it’s time to produce the goods today at home to Hibs  they are to finally get some Premiership points on the board, according to midfield man Paul McGowan.In his usual no-nonsense fashion, McGowan admits the Dark Blues “haven’t been good enough” this season.That’s left them rooted to the foot of the table with no points to their name.The 30-year-old, though, is adamant Dundee have the ability to get themselves out of the trouble they find themselves in.He said: “A bit of luck is just missing for us right now but we need to make our own luck.“We need to start finishing the chances we are creating and we’re not keeping clean sheets.“That doesn’t bode well for trying to get the three points but we need to stick together, start from a clean sheet and then, hopefully, finish off a chance.“Listen, I could sit here and go through all sorts of stuff but it’s time to man up now and be counted.“It will be hard out there, the crowd will be on us a wee bit and rightly so with the way we have started but we need to overcome that and, hopefully, get them onside by putting in a performance.“We need to give them something to shout about because they haven’t had that.”And McGowan says he has no problem with having to deal with a bit of stick from the stands.“The fans have paid money so they’re entitled to have a moan because we’ve not been playing that well,” he added.“We accept that, we’re grown men and  you can’t take criticism then you shouldn’t be in this game.”After a 4-0 tanking at Ibrox last week where the Dark Blues were blown away in the early stages, trailing 2-0 within 15 minutes, McGowan has urged his team-mates to be more streetwise going forward.“You’ve got to weather that first 10, 15 minutes or so and we didn’t.“We gted them two goals and you can’t do that at Ibrox – you can’t do that against any team in this league.“We need to be more streetwise with how the game is going,  we’re under it a bit, just sit in and soak up the pressure until the game settles down a bit. We need to learn that.“Inidual mistakes are costing us and we’re getting punished for them all.“It’s amazing how quickly football can change. At the start of the season we had the chance to go 2-1 up at St Mirren but missed the penalty and then we conceded a freak goal.“Things like that can just turn and luck starts going against you but, listen, we haven’t been good enough.“I’m not going to make excuses or any rubbish like that – we haven’t been good enough and that’s down to the players.“We need to stand up and be counted and start showing how good a football team we are. We need to produce, starting today.“I believe in every one of us that we are good enough to get out of the situation we’re in.“It’s only five games into the season, a couple of wins gets us right up there.“I know we are a good footballing side, it’s the other side we need, being hard to beat and getting clean sheets.”The Dens men come up against a formidable attacking outfit when Neil Lennon’s Hibs come to town – McGowan, though, is certain Dundee can cause some problems of their own.He added: “Hibs are good going forward but they can be got at at the back. They are expansive, have a go, that’s the way Lenny like’s it but he’ll have them well-drilled and well up for it.“It’ll be a big ask for us to get the three points but I’m pretty sure we can.”

title: dundee united boss csaba pleased to have more options for falkirk clash
story: Dundee United manager Csaba Laszlo admits he is relieved to, finally, have close to a full squad to choose from.Csaba will have more at his disposal for the clash at Championship bottom side Falkirk today and could hand starts to key men Fraser Fyvie and Billy King.Both are rated touch and go while Sam Stanton, Nicky Clark and Stewart Murdoch are working their way back to full training.Csaba said: “We have spoken with Fraser and he still hasn’t decided but he is not far enough along psychologically but I think, definitely, he will be part of the squad.“We are looking to protect the player in the long term, not just one game.“It will be a decision between him and me. He has worked very hard and the physios and doctors have done a good job.“You saw on Saturday how important a player he is for our team.“He told me that,  it’s necessary, he would come on to the pitch.“He may not be ready for 90 minutes but I think 45 could be OK for him.“Any decision from his side will be accepted from my side. We need him for long term not just the short term.“Billy King is definitely ready for the game, which is good news. He has trained well.“Sam Stanton has started running and will begin training next week with the team.“Nicky Clark will begin to train next week with the team.“If everything goes good, in one week more or less, we will have everybody back.“We have fought for so long for this.“In a week or two we will have everybody at full power for 90 minutes which I’m happy about.”

title: dundee united captain fraser fyvie set for first start at falkirk
story: Dundee United club captain Fraser Fyvie is set to make his first start of the season at Falkirk on Saturday after working his way back from serious injury.Fyvie had been out since injuring his knee in a 3-0 Championship home win over Livingston in December of last year.The 25-year-old midfielder has since undertaken a phased  to action, coming off the bench against Alloa in the Irn-Bru Cup earlier in the month and at home to Morton in the league last Saturday.In the latter match Fyvie struck a last-minute equaliser to salvage a point for the Terrors after replacing Adam Barton in the 1-1 draw.He continued his recovery on Tuesday – turning out from the start for Dundee United reserves in their 2-1 league defeat to Rangers at St Andrews.It is now hoped the former Aberdeen, Wigan and Hibs man can complete his comeback by leading the Terrors out at the Falkirk Stadium on Saturday afternoon.He could also be joined in the starting XI by a fellow-key man from last season – Billy King.King has also followed the same path back to the pitch as Fyvie – appearing late on against Alloa and Morton and starting in the Gers reserve clash.The 24-year-old is, perhaps, still a bit away from starting a game and the form of Fraser Aird and Yannick Loemba on the flanks does not help his cause.However, he looks likely to keep his place on the bench after bouncing back from troublesome and complicated knee problems that have dogged him for the early part of the season.The former Hearts, Rangers and Inverness man notched eight goals for the Tangerines last time out and is highly-rated by boss Csaba Laszlo.The  of both men to the first-team fold hands the gaffer a boost ahead of Saturday’s crucial clash with Ray MacKinnon’s Bairns side.And Csaba noted the importance of the game after recent disappointing results and displays in the league.He said: “It will soon become more heavy but I hope the fans understand the situation.“We have changed a lot of personnel and, OK, I appreciate always the fans are noisy but on Saturday everybody felt us losing two points.”

title: dundee united defender freddy frans not worried about falkirks artificial pitch
story: After two full seasons in the Championship it is clear being big fish in a small pond has been of no benefit to Dundee United.And that is something Freddy Frans is well aware of with the defender insisting they have to fight to win points in a league where the pressure is always on.Since their relegation from the Premiership in 2016, United have twice fell in the campaign-closing promotion play-offs and currently lie fth in the table after a sticky start.They travel through to Falkirk today to face a Bairns side managed by ex-Terrors boss Ray McKinnon, something which could add an extra element of pressure for Csaba Laszlo’s team.However, 29-year-old Frans insists that is something they must learn to cope with while picking up the points.“That’s one of the reasons why I wanted to play for Dundee United,” he said.“I wanted the pressure. I am not a player made for playing without any pressure because then I wouldn’t be playing well.“I need pressure to thrive and it’s a big club – it should be in the Premiership.“It’s about how we deal with the pressure and Dundee United is probably the team with the most pressure on it in this league.“You feel like the fans definitely want to get out of the Championship. I want to get out of the Championship as well.“I’m not coming here to play my two seasons on my contract in the Championship.“It’s going to be a tough game and, in this league, every game is tough. It’s not because they are bottom of the league that we should underestimate them.“They have a new coach and they showed last week they played very good in the first half and the thing is they have nothing to lose, we have everything to lose.“You see in this league there is not one game you can predict. Everybody can beat each other.”After disappointing draws against Alloa and Morton in recent weeks, Frans knows there can be no more excuses.He has captained the side in the absence of the likes of Fraser Fyvie and Stewart Murdoch and feels they are now more equipped, with their ‘leaders’ coming back to the squad, to go on a winning run.“If you look at the way we played last weekend, we had 11 players starting who weren’t here last year but still we produce some good stuff,” he added.“We need to be more efficient. We missed a few chances but also we concede every game.“I do think we defend well but somehow we concede a penalty and the week before it was a free-kick against Alloa.“It is not because of bad defending, just small things, and we need to get better at them.“I think you see every week we are improving but, OK, there comes a time you need to put it in results and start to go on a run.“You see Fraser Fyvie coming back, Billy King, Sam Stanton is still injured, Murdoch is out.“These are players who would walk into a lot of Championship teams and be the leaders.“There are positive things to look forward to.”United will go toe-to-toe with pointless bottom side Falkirk today on an articial surface.However, Frans says they will not be using that or the ongoing stormy weather as excuses for another disappointing display.“I don’t like to talk about the pitch because I don’t want to have any excuses. Whatever pitch it is we should play well.“We went to Queen of the South and I think the first half we produced one of the best performances since I’ve been here.“You come up against dferent circumstances and maybe it’s going to be 100mph wind.“Every week it’s something so  you think too much about circumstances you are not focused.”

title: falkirk boss ray mckinnon looks ahead to clash with old club dundee united
story: Ray McKinnon accepts there will be an added dimension to this weekend’s game against old club Dundee United because he is only “human”.However, the Falkirk manager is adamant his sole focus will be on trying to land a first league win of the season for his new team.McKinnon will be facing United for the first time since being sacked by the Tangerines in October last year.He was axed just 10 games into the season with the Tannadice outfit in fourth place and just five points off the top of the Championship.He said: “I’m treating it just as another game but I am human, so I am naturally going to look at all the scenarios.“However, the focus will definitely be just on us and making sure we are set up properly.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to be more decisive in front of goal
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann has urged his players to be more decisive in front of goal against Hibs this weekend to finally get some Premiership points on the board.The Dark Blues host Neil Lennon’s men this Saturday still in search of their first positive result of the season and languishing at the foot of the table.With time marching on and teams above them picking up results, pressure is building at Dens Park on the management team.A wee bit of composure in front of goal, however, would be the perfect tonic to lt the spirits at Dens Park against the Hibees, according to gaffer Neil.That would have helped at Ibrox had Elton Ngwatala kept his cool in front of goal, despite being on his weaker side, as he raced beyond the Rangers defence with the score at 2-0.Kenny Miller played in the Frenchman in the 36th minute but Ngwatala dallied on the ball and didn’t even manage to get a shot off despite having just keeper Allan McGregor to beat.Had Dundee made that count, Neil insists the outcome of the match would’ve been dferent.He said: “Elton took an extra touch and I don’t think he needed to.“It was a blistering counter-attack, it was a lovely ball, and he should just take it early but his extra touch allows the defender to recover and doesn’t even make the keeper save.“I definitely believe it would have changed the outcome of the whole match but it’s been the story of our season where we don’t take chances or choose the right decision in the final third.”Poor decision-making has also cost the team dear in defence, with Ngwatala’s missed opportunity compounded shortly afterwards as Darren O’Dea brought Alfredo Morelos down for a penalty moments before half-time to end the match as any kind of contest.Neil added: “I felt we had enough of the game in between the second and third goal.“Darren gets injured and then makes a poor decision in the end because he was struggling.“I had no complaints about the penalty but it was a sore one because we were going in at 2-0 with us well in the game.”More frustration would follow for the Dark Blues as key man Kenny Miller saw red for a rash challenge while already on a yellow card.Referee Kevin Clancy brandished a straight red card for the tackle on Gers full-back Borna Barisic.The former Celtic, Wolves and Rangers striker will miss Saturday’s clash with another of his old clubs Hibs and the following trip to Hamilton after the club’s appeal against the decision was unsuccessful.And Miller says he’s “disappointed” to be missing out when his new club is desperate to turn their dreadful opening to the campaign around.Miller said: “Anyone who knows me knows I am not a dirty player.“My eyes were firmly on the ball throughout.“I went wholeheartedly to win the ball. I did win the ball but on the follow-through there is always going to be contact.“We have watched it back and I am actually pulling my leg away as soon as I touched the ball to try to minimise the contact.“I never went in to harm anybody and I think the red was brandished too quickly.“I have been in the game a long time but I have never gone in to hurt anybody.“It was an honest, genuine attempt to play the ball which I did.“So it is disappointing I am going to miss two games after just going to a new club.”

title: this weekend farewell parade for maggies penguins in dundee ahead of auction
